results.snippet: During a meeting of several thousand aerospace scientists in Washington yesterday, a French-born countess and philanthropist announced the creation of an award for scientific contributions to the field of aerospace.   Declaring her faith in the...
results.lead_paragraph: During a meeting of several thousand aerospace scientists in Washington yesterday, a French-born countess and philanthropist announced the creation of an award for scientific contributions to the field of aerospace. Declaring her faith in the benefits of aerospace research, Countess ALBINA DU BOISROUVRAY told the World Space Congress at the Washington Convention Center that she had established a $250,000 Francois-Xavier Bagnoud Aerospace Prize "to encourage the advancement" of related sciences. The prize, to be awarded every two years, is named for the Countess's son, a pilot who had dreamed of becoming an astronaut but who died in a helicopter crash in Mali in 1986, at the age of 24. The first prize is scheduled to be awarded in the fall of 1993.

headline.main: Shuttle Called Fixed and Set to Go

results.snippet: Technicians at the Kennedy Space Center here have repaired a leaking fuel valve on the shuttle Endeavour, leading the space agency to announce that it will stand by its plans to launch its 50th shuttle mission next Saturday.   Flight preparations...
results.lead_paragraph: Technicians at the Kennedy Space Center here have repaired a leaking fuel valve on the shuttle Endeavour, leading the space agency to announce that it will stand by its plans to launch its 50th shuttle mission next Saturday. Flight preparations were interrupted when the leak was discovered early this week, and the problem had threatened to delay the weeklong mission.

headline.main: Balloonists Will Try Again to Circle Globe

results.snippet: Larry Newman, captain of a team of aeronauts who hope to make the first nonstop balloon flight around the world, announced this week that their Earthwinds balloon would be ready to launch from Reno Stead Airport in Nevada on Nov. 15.   A previous...
results.lead_paragraph: Larry Newman, captain of a team of aeronauts who hope to make the first nonstop balloon flight around the world, announced this week that their Earthwinds balloon would be ready to launch from Reno Stead Airport in Nevada on Nov. 15. A previous attempt by the group to launch Earthwinds from Akron, Ohio, was abandoned last February when surface winds became too strong to handle the huge balloon on the ground. Winds at the Nevada site are expected to be much milder for a longer period, and Mr. Newman said weather would be favorable from Nov. 15 until the end of February.

headline.main: Animals Loaded and Crew Is Set For a U.S.-Japan Shuttle Mission

results.snippet: Technicians today loaded carp, frogs and other animals aboard the space shuttle Endeavour as they completed final preparations for a seven-day cooperative space mission involving the United States and Japan.   Mission controllers said weather...
results.lead_paragraph: Technicians today loaded carp, frogs and other animals aboard the space shuttle Endeavour as they completed final preparations for a seven-day cooperative space mission involving the United States and Japan. Mission controllers said weather appeared to be the only factor that could delay the launching scheduled for 10:23 A.M. on Saturday. The mission of Endeavour and its crew of seven astronauts is viewed as a prelude to what could become routine international cooperation aboard the proposed Space Station Freedom. Weather forecasters predicted a 70 percent chance of acceptable weather.

headline.main: U.S.-JAPAN MISSION IS A SHUTTLE FIRST

results.snippet: The first cooperative space shuttle mission of the United States and Japan got off with unusual punctuality today as a crew of seven rose to orbit aboard the shuttle Endeavour after a nearly flawless countdown.   The 50th flight of the shuttle...
results.lead_paragraph: The first cooperative space shuttle mission of the United States and Japan got off with unusual punctuality today as a crew of seven rose to orbit aboard the shuttle Endeavour after a nearly flawless countdown. The 50th flight of the shuttle program left the launching pad at exactly 10:23 A.M., the first flight since 1985 to get off precisely on time.

headline.main: Woman in the News; A Determined Breaker of Boundaries -- Mae Carol Jemison

results.snippet: As a young girl growing up on the South Side of Chicago, Mae C. Jemison watched telecasts of the Gemini and Apollo spaceflights and knew that that was her destiny. No matter that all the astronauts were male and white and that she was female and...
results.lead_paragraph: As a young girl growing up on the South Side of Chicago, Mae C. Jemison watched telecasts of the Gemini and Apollo spaceflights and knew that that was her destiny. No matter that all the astronauts were male and white and that she was female and black. She simply knew she would be a space traveler. Now a 35-year-old doctor and engineer, Dr. Jemison has realized her dream, launching into orbit yesterday as one of the shuttle Endeavor's seven-member crew. In the process she has become the first African-American woman to go into space.

headline.main: Astronauts Study Motion Sickness On Second Day of Shuttle Mission

results.snippet: Two astronauts conducted experiments today aboard the space shuttle Endeavour in an effort to solve the mysteries of motion sickness.   Another astronaut, Col. Mark C. Lee of the Air Force, repaired a leaking cooling system that had delayed other...
results.lead_paragraph: Two astronauts conducted experiments today aboard the space shuttle Endeavour in an effort to solve the mysteries of motion sickness. Another astronaut, Col. Mark C. Lee of the Air Force, repaired a leaking cooling system that had delayed other major experiments. The cooling system, which is used for science equipment on the shuttle, was discovered leaking when the shuttle reached orbit after launch from Florida on Saturday.

headline.main: Sketches of the 7 Astronauts Aboard Shuttle Endeavour

results.snippet: Robert L. Gibson  Mission Commander   Captain Gibson, a 45-year-old former Navy fighter pilot, is making his fourth space flight. He became an astronaut in 1979.
results.lead_paragraph: Robert L. Gibson Mission Commander Captain Gibson, a 45-year-old former Navy fighter pilot, is making his fourth space flight. He became an astronaut in 1979.

headline.main: Crew on Shuttle Fertilize Eggs, A Space First

results.snippet: The shuttle Endeavour's astronauts learned today that eggs produced by frogs in orbit had been successfully fertilized in space.   "It's the first time we've had ovulation in a higher species, in this case the amphibian," said the principal...
results.lead_paragraph: The shuttle Endeavour's astronauts learned today that eggs produced by frogs in orbit had been successfully fertilized in space. "It's the first time we've had ovulation in a higher species, in this case the amphibian," said the principal investigator, Dr. Ken Souza of NASA's Ames Research Center in Mountain View, Calif. "We've also had fertilization," he added. "We now know that the eggs can be fertilized in the absence of gravity."

results.snippet: A dance-company poster might seem an unlikely item for an astronaut to carry into space, but Dr. MAE C. JEMISON, now on the shuttle Endeavor, was determined to bring along some memento of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.    The first black...
results.lead_paragraph: A dance-company poster might seem an unlikely item for an astronaut to carry into space, but Dr. MAE C. JEMISON, now on the shuttle Endeavor, was determined to bring along some memento of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. The first black woman to become an astronaut, Dr. Jemison, a 35-year-old physician and chemical engineer, wrote to JUDITH JAMISON, director of the company, asking to borrow a costume.

headline.main: Shuttle Lands, Ending Japanese Research Mission

results.snippet: Ending the first shuttle flight devoted to Japanese research, the space shuttle Endeavour landed at the Kennedy Space Center today with seven astronauts, two carp, four frogs and assorted tadpoles, hornets and flies.   The five-man, two-woman crew...
results.lead_paragraph: Ending the first shuttle flight devoted to Japanese research, the space shuttle Endeavour landed at the Kennedy Space Center today with seven astronauts, two carp, four frogs and assorted tadpoles, hornets and flies. The five-man, two-woman crew made history not only with their mission but also because of who they are: the first married couple in space, the first black woman in space and the first Japanese astronaut on an American spaceship.
